One of the most common objects I design are tube collars, i.e. adapters that fit on a tube and make it wider. This makes it possible to clamp things to tubes that are not wide enough.   
It doesn't take long to make one of these adapters, since they basically always look the same. It is however a bit boring, so I made a customizable version. Just enter the desired height etc in the customizer to create your own collar for your specific need.
Hinge designed by Pratt student, Russell.

This is redesign of the Gluss Pusher stator. The Autodesk Fusion 360 files are: https://myhub.autodesk360.com/ue29b4247/shares/public/SHabee1QT1a327cf2b7a31ae28f6f2630611 This fixes the problem (for me) that the first version had the bobbins incorrectly spaced. I'm not sure this will be valuable to anyone except as a bit of an idea for a starting point. Note that the back end has a female cut out to receive the "stator tube". I plan to completely redesign this; this is just a waypoint as part of the design process, although it certainly functions and is better than the last version. The original design is: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:981840

This was printed with a MakerBot 2 in PLA.  Possibly ABS would be better for a coil bobbin because the coils do get hot---that has not been a problem for me yet.  
There is danger of sagging, but I used "Simplify3D" to add support structures.  That program is pricey but excellent for adding supports.  I personally print it standing up---in a "vertical" position, because the interior hole is the most dimensionally important measure.  I then use a bit of sandpaper on a drill bit to clean out the whole from stray plastic, making a nice smooth interior hole.

I needed to build a 36 inch Wheel of Fortune so wanted to make one for use with a standard cheap wooden yardstick that is readily available at any home improvement centers paint dept. I also doubled the overall size and had to make this 2 prints instead of a single plate.   
Let me know what you think. This is a really useful piece for almost any workshop.   
Thanks magtech

We made this mannequin for use in a stop motion video, it has fully articulated limbs and if positioned carefully you can print the joints in one piece.  
The video was made as a promo for our campaign to take our makerspace around Australia so if you get a chance please check out our campaign at pozible.com/makermachine.com

Print all the parts, the 2 leg and arm parts will need to be printed twice each. snap the parts together.  
we found that the joints after a bit of use would loosen up, putting a small piece of blue tack in the socket of the joint helped itt hold its position.

description.text: Small mug holder/hook for in dorm.

Wentworth Woodhouse is Europe’s largest private residence and, in my opinion, one of the greatest houses the world has ever seen. Brief History:
Based just outside of Rotherham, UK, there has been a house on the site for hundreds of years, however, building for the Baroque style western front started in 1723. However, the architectural tastes of political elites soon changed and in 1734, before the western front had been completed, work commenced on the eastern front which was Palladian in style. This therefore makes Wentworth Woodhouse actually two houses. The houses were built and occupied by Thomas Watson-Wentworth, 1st Marquess of Rockingham who died in 1750 which meant the house was inherited by Charles Watson-Wentworth, 2nd Marquess of Rockingham who added many extensions to the house including the towers on the end of the eastern front. The house then passed to the Earls Fitzwilliam who eventually sold the house in 1989. The house was in a poor state of repair and suffered from subsidence thought to be caused by mining coal close to the house. It was bought by Clifford Newbold who spent a lot of time and money resorting parts of the house. After he passed away in 2014 the House was offered for sale in early 2015 for only £8 million, however, it was claimed to need over £50 million worth of repairs. The model:
This model is only of the eastern Palladian front. However, I do intend to finish the house by modelling the western front sometime in late 2015 or early 2016. There are 3 parts to the model (centre section and two outer wings). The outer wings have “hooks” on them which slot into a corresponding channel in the centre section. No glue is needed for assembly but some trimming or sanding may be required depending on your printer settings. I would advise printing the model with a layer height of 0.1mm as this will give good definition on the roof. The model doesn't need much fill so I only used a density of 10%. I printed in PLA @ 205 deg nozzle temperature and 55 deg bed temperature. If you like this print then please have a look at my other print of Heveningham Hall. I intend to make many more houses too.

There is another Pinard horn on Thingiverse, but it's small and not designed to print well, so I made my own. This one is more realistically sized and designed to be printed in thin-wall vase mode with a wall thickness of 0.8mm and 0.6mm bottom thickness.  
This makes a good souvenir gift for your aunt who is a midwife, FYI.

Print in thin-wall vase mode with extrusion thickness of 0.8mm and bottom thickness of 0.6mm (three layers at 0.2mm layer height, for instance). You'll have to use a knife to trim out the floor in the bottom  inside of the tube, but it's pretty easy to do. Also don't forget to make sure you smooth out any jaggies on the trumpet end so that you don't poke or scratch someone's belly. I covered the flat end of mine with a felt ring so that it's more comfortable against your ear.

Heveningham Hall is a large country house located in Suffolk, England. It is one of the largest in the country and is surrounded by well-kept rolling country side. Brief History:
The current house was built in 1778 by Sir Robert Taylor, thus making it a rather late style of English Palladianism. The house was commissioned and occupied by Sir Gerard Vanneck who was a dutch merchant. The interiors of the house were completed by notable architect James Wyatt. The house was owned by the Vanneck family until 1970 when death duties forced the sale of the house. The house was bought by English Heritage until its sale in 1981 to an Iraqi businessman. The East Wing of the house was damaged by a fire in 1984 and was not entirely repaired until 1991. In 1994 the house was once again sold to its current owner who still uses it as a private house. Furthermore, the current owner has restored all of the surrounding land to the original designs by Capability Brown. It is now arguable that the house and grounds are in better condition than when they were newly finished. The Model:
This model prints as once piece therefore scaling may be required. The model retains most of its scale down to around the 50% scale mark. Making a model of this would seriously affect its quality. I used a 0.1mm layer height for this model as this gives an excellent finish to the roof. The model does not require much fill so I use a density of 10%. If you like this model then please have a look at my other model of Wentworth Woodhouse. More large houses on the way!

title: T4 Mini 315 Remix (fasteners instead of zip ties)

description.text:
I modified the body and bottom tray of this great design because I wanted to use fasteners instead of zip ties to keep it together. I created "pockets" on the body and the bottom tray in which M3 nuts can be inserted. Then I also incorporated small structures inside both parts (body and bottom tray) through which M3 fasteners can be installed. The top plate was slightly modified to include the holes for the new fasteners.  
The bottom tray was also modified (made higher) in order to fit the 4 30 Amp ESCs that I (incorrectly) chose for this quad. I removed the air inlets on the body because my Printrbot-like Reprap was having difficulties  printing them (also the body became more rigid without those holes and refrigeration is still OK).

UPDATE!
As Cobblebot is completely shitty and useless printer done by two arrogant knobs and it just doesn't work as advertised ... well, it just doesn't work at all without loads of mods, I have moved the X&Y to the top frame and that requires more sturdy mount ... so the mount v2 has now holes for two M5 screws make sure it won't move when it changes directions. If there will be anyone interested, I will be happy to post photos of my mods to a separate post, just let me know. Original message:
Just received a cobblebot from kickstarter and found out rhere is a couple of things I don't like so far ... I have bought a couple of pulleys instead of using the ones designed by cobblebot. The next thing I had no idea how to do was how to mount the X and Y belts onto the rails so I have created these two holders. Holder one is designed to be mounted using M5 bolt into the rail and holds the belt ... use a couple of washers to keep it tight. The other one has two "wings so you can mount in through the hotend mounts in the middle using just two electrical cable ties. After printing it on my old printer I found that the holes for M3 tightening (closing) holes are too small so I used a drill to clean them nicely.

With this file you can generate 3D shadows of all of the isogonal (vertex equivalent) truncations of the 4D Hypercube.  The convex uniform (using only regular polygons) examples can be selected from a drop down menu.  Each of the objects can be viewed from any direction in 4D.  
If the viewpoint gets inside the polytope then weird things happen.  But, it the viewpoint is close to the edge of the polytope then the shadow is a Schegel diagram, which is usually makes it easier to see what is going on.  
I'll be adding some of the non-convex examples to the drop down menu when I get the figured out.

I couldn't find an acceptable easy-to-print and strong flex hose, so I made this one. It's a solid part that has appropriate reinforcements around the base where it's weak,.. seriously, it takes a lot of force just to snap these together, but they're fairly air tight and they hold their shape pretty well. My big desire in making this was a piece that wasn't just a shell, but was actually solid inside, so I made this from scratch using FreeCAD to end up with good wall thickness and also very tight tolerances.  
I print them with a raft, open side down, and it's best to snap them together if you warm up one side a bit. You'll get the hand after a couple pieces if your hands don't hurt too much :) Don't force them straight on, kind of wobble them on in large motions.  
Another thing I do is set the diameter of my filament to .32mm so that it overprints the walls and creates an even stronger part (it's actually .4mm)  
Once they're together, if you find that some air is slipping (because they were too cold when snapped or because the material you used fractured) you can either put a bit of heat shrink tubing just barely over where they connect, like, maybe 3/8 or 1/4 in wide band over where the ball and socket meet, but just be sure the majority is on the socket side and not the ball side, and when you heat the heat shrink, don't move the pieces or the PLA joint will get weak and tear.  
I'll post a picture of that if anyone is interested. Another thing you can do is dab a little acetone on the ball after they're connected (you have to let it work in between the ball and socket,) let it sit for 5-10 seconds, then move it just a bit around and blow on it to evaporate the excess, that gives it a nice smooth flow, but it does reduce the friction slightly depending on how much you add so be careful. It improves air leakage too though.  
I'm feeding these with an air compressor, so, they're quite strong and air-worthy, I hope you enjoy! :D

comments.text: Yeah I can imagine it would be pretty difficult to print them at half the size I used. You could try a couple things though, one thing that comes to mind is heating them up before trying to pretty them together. Also, when you press them together, don't press them directly into eachother, instead come in at an angle with the ball part into the socket and rotate them around as you apply force. Even at 100% these left my hands sore, but at that size they're incredibly strong, so at the smaller size don't apply to much force, they should eventually deform enough to snap together. Heat should help too but be careful not to heat the middle part up, that'll cause it to become even weaker.you can also sand the ball part down just a bit or use a sharp knife to cut out a bit of the socket around the inside (give it more of a bevel) too. Dipping it into acetone quickly will also make it just a bit "stretchy".. I quote that because.. well you'll see when you try, it's not exactly "stretchy" but kinda.. :)

title: Quick Change Spool Supports for 2020 Prusa i3

description.text:
I like the bearing supported spool holder design, but wanted it to be easier to change spools quicker and easier.  I have my printer in a cabinet that didn't really leave lots of room to pull the threaded rod out to the left or right.  It was also a tight space to put the spool, bearing cones, etc. on and thread on the nuts.  With this change, you can put the spool, cones, inserts, and nuts on the threaded rod, tighten it down, and have it ready to just drop into the arms.  The arms hold the spool rod insert securely, without any risk of it falling out, yet it is easy to slip in and out.  
I also added a small spool cone that works better with the spools with a small center opening.  It is design to use 608 bearings.  If you don't use a spool cone, you are missing out on the very low resistance a bearing supported center mount spool holder can provide.
The purpose of the round insert is so you can quickly and easily thread the nuts onto the threaded rods and tighten (not too tight!) the spool cones into the spool, then just drop the full assembly onto the arms.  You can skip the inserts if you prefer to put the nuts between the arms and the spool cone, but I like how tight and secure it keeps everything.  
The arm has holes on each side of the bottom for the arm shim but I only use the ones in front.  I like the hole on the front for easy access - the hole is just on both sides so the same part can be used facing to the left or the right.  The shims are not t-nuts, and are loose enough in the slot to allow you to slide the arms left and right to accommodate any spool thickness quickly, without tools, but still holds the arm on securely, keeping it from tipping over or coming off.  
I'm using this on a FolgerTech 2020 Prusa i3.  I love the very low resistance you get with a center bearing supported spool holder directly above the extruder.  Pretty much eliminates any potential quality issues related to filament feed resistance.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 or 0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes: I used 0.3 just because it was quicker, and high resolution isn't required, but 0.2 works fine too.

To put the rod together, put on the spool, and a bearing cone on each side, then one of the inserts against the bearing, with the longer end towards the bearing.  Thread the nuts on, and you are ready to drop the spool into the holders.  The supports mount the same as the previous design, using the 2020 inserts included in that project to hold the uprights in place, while still letting it move side-to-side.
When mounting the arms, you just need one shim on the front.  The holes are on both sides so you can face the arm either direction.  Using just one hole will keep the arm on securely and prevent any tipping over.  Use the shim rather than a T-nut so you can freely slide the arm left and right, to fit spools of different thickness.

My wife, and her old sorority, are big fans of the Fleur De Lis. (A decorative lily.)
Also used (in various forms) by scouts, sports teams, and many others. When I finished assembling, testing, and calibrating my Thing-O-Matic, This was my first print as a way to thank her for indulging my nerdy obsessions. I didn't design it, I pulled it off the Google Sketchup warehouse. It can be found here http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=4cf07fb6cf4105169eeaab05b21288d and design should be credited to user Frisky Dingo.

Should not be difficult to print.
Nothing needs support. It turned out very nice even when my initial calibration of my bot was running at 60mm/s feed rate. (Before I got to more complex prints and realized this was a bad thing for a noob like myself!)

author: muxa4ever

description.text:
I've been playing Takenoko quite a while recently, and find it to be a great board game.
The one thing I felt needed a little improvement, however, was the fact that I had to either hold the objective cards in my hands (which is uncomfortable, as hands are needed to perform game actions) or memorize them (which is equally uncomfortable, as I keep forgetting them and need to look at them very often).
I then decided to design an objective card holder, to both help with ongoing objectives (facing the player) and completed objectives (facing the opponents).
We've been using them for a while now, and I believe they make the game easier to play.
They are designed to be long enough to hold 3 objective cards without overlap, but they can easily hold 5 or 6 cards with a bit of overlap.
The slots for the completed objectives cards can hold up to 12 cards, which is more than I have ever needed (my best game ended with 11 completed objectives, including the Emperor Card). The card holders fit in the original box, inside the compartment for the water irrigation canals. Two of them fit very nicely, if you need more than two you can place them inside the box, under the plastic blister that holds all the components. It is very possible that this card holder can also work for board games that use cards similar to the ones Takenoko has (4.5 x 6.5 cm), if you don't mind it having "Takenoko" written on it... :)

This has been printed on my Arduino Materia 101 in black PLA.
Layers are 0.2mm thick, infill is a 20% honeycomb, and it needs no supports for printing.

I wanted more space on the top plate of my ZMR 250 to hold the Nano-Tech 3S 1300mah LIPO and mobius mount so I utilized the arm plate from this frame design on thingiverse.com http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:842834 I removed all of the unnecessary holes except for one hole on each of the arm areas. The top plate will be attached to the ZMR 250 frame using aluminum standoffs at these holes. The Nano-Tech 3S 1300mah LIPO fits nice and snug inside the center box area. I created elongated slots on each side to run a Velcro strap through them. For convenience, I used an XT60 connector holder from another thingiverse.com design and integrated that into the plate. The large 7mm holes at one end of the plate next to the XT60 holder are used to attach the video transmitter antenna. The holes and grid pattern slots on the opposite side of the plate are used to attached a Mobius camera mount. I created the design in Tinkercad.
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iEnY7k3THtf Print in PLA using your favorite settings.
AA battery pack that allows a USB (or other) permanent connection instead of batteries.

This prints well without supports, tested with 3mm HIPS. Some battery compartments are a little tighter, so on my to-do list is a modified smaller version.  
Strip a standard USB cable (or find a 3V power source, USB is 5V but generally tolerable for 3V devices), you want the red and the black cables. I soldered these onto standard car terminal connectors and then bent them around once in the battery pack. Working so far in powering an old 2x AA powered camera I can now have as a permanently powered camera.

comments.text: I realised later that the build does have supports as I cut-out the centre between the 2 batteries (you can see the block support in the pictures). This allows for a tighter fitting without (hopefully) the wires getting trapped. If you find it a bit tight for your uses, easy enough to simply scale the whole thing down by 1-5% without it causing too many other issues.

This is my version of the following design found on thingiverse.com
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:997264 I removed the beveled base and made it flat, around 3mm on each side. It's meant to be glued onto the ZMR 250 frame. It was designed in Tinkercad.
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/l73zNel5noJ Print in PLA using your favorite settings.

I wanted to take advantage of tilted motors for stability but did not want to have the motors titled forward as with most 10 degree motor mounts. I am not an FPV racer, so I designed these spacers. I created the design in Tinkercad.
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eIQ8WqBlmC5 You may not commercially produce this part. It's for personal use only.

Two spacers are required for each arm and will therefore require longer screws than are supplied with the ZMR 250 frame. One goes below the arm and the other on top at opposite angles. When installed between the arm plates:
  • The arm is tilted 10 degrees towards the ZMR frame.
  • The space between the arm plates is increased.
    • You can utilize only one spacer between the bottom arm plate and the arm if you wish but then you will need to connect the top arm plate to the bottom arm plate via other means such as small aluminum spacers via different mounting holes. I just used a small aluminum standoff on one of the four arm mounting screws instead of a nut. Print in PLA using your favorite settings.

title: Pimodules UPS PIco lid for Raspberry Pi 2 modular case

description.text:
The original lids weren't tall enough to fit the UPS PIco hat and the plastic pins in the back interfered with the board.
This is a new 10mm taller lid hastily cobbled together in sketchup from the original STL, with the pins removed and a battery tray hanging off the side, specifically for the Pimodules UPS Pico with large battery addon pack. Hopefully someone finds it useful :) The press fit isn't as good with the pins in the back removed, either use tape or some form of clamp to hold the parts firmly together!

author: ssvenn

description.text:
Off to do some photography on the coast soon and wanted some thing to stop my tripod sinking in to the sand. It needs to fit my Manfrotto 190Xprob tripod.  
The fitting and the joint are a little loose for my liking hopefully some thing that will change as it evolves.  
I'll let you know how it performs when I get back.  
On soft sand it worked well it barley marked the surface. 
However the joint was a little too loose for my liking and often fell apart, also one of the arms on the upper part broke off, resulting in having to place the pad first then placing the tripod on top.
I've also cleaned up the open SCAD file which should make it easier to adjust.
Enjoy Let me know what you think.

title: Simple Interface for DLP Printers running Marlin

description.text: Simple DLP Panel is designed to be a simple, easy-to-implement and easy-to-use front panel interface for your DLP printer. It provides three buttons, Up, Down, and Home, which let you quickly move the stage of a single-axis DLP printer running Marlin firmware without having to turn to your computer and use a fancy GUI. The software is a simple modification to the great Marlin Firmware; the modified version is hosted here. The parts provided fit well on an OpenBeam or other 15-mm aluminum extrusion, but can be easily modified to fit other printer types. WARNING: The buttons on this interface are not disabled during a print. You can mess up your print or break your print bed by pressing them at the wrong time! Don't come crying to me!

• A printer running Marlin on some motherboard (RAMPS is popular; this was developed using Printrboard)
  • 3 Push Buttons (I used this part from Jameco). They should be Normally Open (pushing the button closes the circuit)
  • 2 M3 Screws and whatever nut/T-Nut your printer frame needs
  • One printed Button Panel
  • Some wire and basic soldering skills
Get the modified Marlin firmware. You can either download it directly from my GitHub fork or apply a patch to your own Marlin build. See below:

Go to my GitHub fork and click Download Zip. Open Marlin/Marlin.ino in Arduino, and make whatever changes you need to in Configuration.h to make this work with your printer. If you are using any motherboard besides Printrboard, you'll need to add a few lines to Pins.h to specify which pins you want to use for the three buttons. Instructions are in the Readme.  
Build the solution using Arduino and upload it to your printer.

description.header: Patching your own copy of Marlin
description.text:
The Git Patch is available in the Downloads section. It contains all the changes to a typical Marlin firmware needed to implement the simple DLP interface. It will not work with other LCD panels. To apply the patch, download Git (if you don't already have it) and open a terminal in your Marlin folder. Use the following command to merge the changes from the patch into your working directory:
git apply Marlin1.0.2-1_Patch_for_Button_Mod.patch For more details, see this article. If you are using any motherboard besides Printrboard, you'll need to add a few lines to Pins.h to specify which pins you want to use for the three buttons. Instructions are in the Readme. Rebuild and flash your printer with the new firmware using your normal upload procedure.

Each button is wired between a spare pin and ground. When the button is pressed, the pin gets shorted to ground and the printer knows it's time to do something. If you are using Printrboard, the pin assignments are as follows:
Up: Pin 33 = PE1 = Pin 11 on EXP2
Down: Pin 28 = PD4 = Pin 5 on EXP2
Home Pin 30 = PD6 = Pin 7 on EXP2 If you're using another motherboard, make sure you match your wiring to the pins you chose in pins.h. Be sure to use normal safety precautions when soldering!

Print one of the Button Panel parts from the Downloads section. Each of the buttons should fit through one of the three holes in the front of the panel and tighten using the included nut. The two M3 bolts go through the smaller holes and into the nuts in your OpenBeam/80-20/etc frame.

Always test that the buttons function correctly before trying a first print. By default, Marlin won't let you move towards the Home switch until you've run the Home command at least once, so if your Up button isn't working, try Homing first. Note that the Home button on the front panel requires you to hold it down for a couple of seconds before homing begins. This keeps you from accidentally pressing it by mistake. To disable the delay, edit SimpleDlpPlanel.h and change SIMPLE_DLP_HOME_DELAY from 10000 to 1. WARNING: The buttons on this interface are not disabled during a print. You can mess up your print or break your print bed by pressing them at the wrong time!

Construction play set for development of CoreXY printer of any build volume up to 18" cubed. Uses Makerslide components and 1/2" Schedule 40 PVC pipe. Suggested for advanced hobbyists whose projects require non-standard build volumes. This project is a proof of concept, for experimental and informational purposes only. The CoreXY reference mechanism is found here: http://corexy.com/theory.html

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm layer height

Infill:

50%

Notes: ABS is required. All parts can be printed on any machine which has a build volume of 4"x4"x4" or larger. 2 perimeters, 4 bottom layers, 4 top layers, 60mm/sec print speed. The small holes and reinforcement ribs require no support, so the ability to manually remove supports is a good thing. Simplify3D is recommended. Many of the parts require no support.
Apply acetone to the exterior of the parts for increased strength.  You will spend many contemplative hours removing supports. Sandpaper will come in handy.
Trial and error.

Despite the comically high part count, this is a very easy build.  Time consuming, but easy. Each part name has a number in parentheses which indicates the number of parts which should be printed for the model shown (12"x18"x18" build volume).
M6 threaded rod was used for Z-axis motion, which is a poor choice but readily available.  The extruder carriage was designed for a Printrbot direct drive extruder which was also on hand, but a good choice.
You will need many hundreds of #6 sheet metal screws and washers.  The Makerslide components use M5 socket head cap screw of various lengths between 8mm and 30mm.
Determine the build volume you require and cut the PVC and Makerslide accordingly, making allowances for the width of the carriages (I allowed 5 inches).  The lengths don't have to be exactly the same; a variance of plus or minus 1/8" should be fine. The design allows a bit of wiggle room for correct alignment.
The diagonal support struts are of arbitrary length and placement.
Test fit all parts before final assembly, using only one sheet metal screw per part, inserted halfway.  A fully inserted screw creates a nub on the pipe which makes it difficult to reposition.  If that's the case, use the "Smacking Tool" part and a small hammer to move things along.  Be gentle.
UPDATE 22-Jul-16:  Added "idler restraint" to prevent idlers from creeping up.  It may happen, depending on the idlers you use.

comments.text: Like the source of this remix, totally brilliant!  Sorry I missed the remixes when I first saw the original.  Curious to know how well it works or worked...
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: As a proof of concept, it performs...adequately.   The frame itself seems fine, but some of the parts that are under belt tension look like they are deforming slightly over time.  I used ABS; perhaps PetG would be a better material, or the parts should be reworked.  This is not an easy project to troubleshoot, and the wiring is still giving me fits.  A proper cable chain arrangement is eluding me and this project is low priority at this time.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Mayne if I scaled it down the loads on the parts would be less and I could use an 0.4mm nozzle or even an 0.2mm for fine details.   Hmmmmm, tempting.  I could also look into casting the parts out of hard resin....

description.text: I needed 15 cable holders to hold the TV aerial cable in its new position. The hardware only sold packs of 25. So instead of wasting money and having no use for the extra 10 units, I decided to print only as many as I needed.

Pretty simple hop into the openscad file, put in your required dimensions, print only as many as you need, when you need them so they don't get stored and forgotten in some organiser draw.  
Place a small nail in the hole at one end of the holder and bang away to secure that cable.  
The STL file included is for a 6 mm cable (I found if you slightly exaggerate this dimension it works better).

description.text: Version 2 of my orginal razor scraper here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:249012 This one is two piece, requiring you to glue the razor scraper to the handle. I made it this way so that when you print it you dont have to clean out the slot making it much more easier to insert the blade. Also its much more stronger then the original. I had requests for blade cover, so I've included one. Its a tight fitting lid, sand it to your liking if desired. For the lid hinge, I used a piece of 1.75mm filament. You can use whatever(coat hanger, metal rod, etc).

Printed mine using the low defaults on my Rep 2x: For both parts I suggest:
Infill = 33%
Shells = 2
Layer Height = 0.30mm Make sure you print the scraper head vertical like shown in the picture. Also make sure you super glue the scraper head to the handle using a liberal amount of glue. Enjoy! The handle was printed with supports on. The rest of the parts shouldnt need it. I didnt use rafts for anything.

title: SOLO taxonomy stamps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is set of SOLO taxonomy stamps for grading student work. Good as a quick way to give feedback on the thinking that students are exhibiting in their work. The symbols are used by permission of Pam Hook:
http://pamhook.com/solo-taxonomy/

These stamps were printed directly onto a smooth build surface (Kapton tape) to ensure a flat stamp surface. They may not work as well printed on a raft or a textured surface.  
The OpenSCAD files take a long time to render due to the minkowski sum of the DXF file. When I was designing them I used a stripped down version of the script for quick response. When I had everything ready I saved the five different scripts and used the batch file to generate the STLs.

author: Picuber15

title: Custom Thrustmaster TH8RS / TH8A Shiftplates (6, 5, 4 gears + BMW M3 E30 Style)

description.text:
The shiftplaes are a work-in-progress. I'm going to add a sequential shiftplate and a handbrake-like plate in the future. I experimented with acetone treatment after printing. I might share some pictures in a bit. The six geared short and long versions are well tested and feel very smooth. The short versions feel much more direct than their original alloy counterpart.
Since the four and five gear plates are based on the well tested six gear design there shouldn't be any major problems either. The BMW M3 E30 design is "upside down". When mounting it you have to rotate the TH8RS/TH8A 180°. This leads to the resting position of the lever being between the 2nd and 3rd gear. Feel free to leave any feedback, especially if you have any suggestions for improvements. If you'd like to see a different layout it might be worth a try to ask for it.

This is a UNSC device that can be seen in the mid-mission cutscene of 343 Guilty Spark from Halo: Combat Evolved. It is a door hacking device used to gain access to the Forerunner structure seen in the game. This prop was modeled for use with a 5th generation iPod Video along with a LCD screen with component input from the iPod. The keypad area was left blank so back-lit keys could be added later. There are also holes for small magnets so the access panel can be easily removed.

name = Rahman

Inspired by the geometry of an artichoke and Louis Poulsen's great lighting studies and diagrams. This beautiful lamp shade is perfect for the home or business. You can use any standard hanging light cord and a low temp bulb (such as a cfl bulb.) We purchased a standard lamp base with a 12 ft cord from amazon and it screws in the top hole with no issues. 40% infill, high cooling, slow speed. May be tricky on some printers so you may need support for some of the lower fins. Notes:
The model was created in 3ds Max 2011 but due to the inch/mm unit issues the model is scaled up by 2540%. Check out http://www.gcreate.com for information on our Large Format gMax 1.5 + 3D Printers

The file was made in 3ds Max 2011. We started with two sets of fins offset by 30 degrees. These fins were designed to hide the light source while allowing for reflected light. The profiles were also created to allow for printing on an FFF printer.  
After several passes at the perfect shape, the entire model was arrayed radially to create the full lamp shade. We finished by using a boolean union to make it manifold.

comments.text: Any specific speed, or layer settings?
comments.author: MinnesotaMade

comments.text: The speed is very printer dependent. On the gMax 1.5+ we print it at around 130mm/sec movement speed, 70mm/sec print speed with 60% perimeter speeds. You can also try printing with z-axis lift to avoid the tricky overhangs. As for layer height it is really up to the effect you are going for. We personally like seeing the cascade of layers (as the light shines) so we prefer a thicker layer height of around 240 microns.
comments.author: MinnesotaMade

comments.text: Looks cool but I can't imagine how long that file will take to print.
comments.author: ozziegn

comments.text: The print time is dependent on the printer and the filament. We printed one shade in around 20+ hours using a simulated wood fill by Polymaker but we still had a lot of stringing so we still have to tweak the settings. We printed another in Protopasta carbon fiber PLA which looks absolutely stunning (Photos coming soon) and i think it was around 17-18 hours. The model requires a high level of cooling or slower speeds which will increase the time.
comments.author: ozziegn

title: Improved no-glue Internal Parts Lightsaber with pre-ribbed body1

description.text: I couldn't get a very high-quality print of the ribs on my saber, so I edited the file to add the ribs directly to body1.stl. The overhang won't come out quite as pretty, but the ribs themselves will look much better without having to sit on the bed. I found that when I printed it, the overhangs acutally came out pretty cleanly on a TAZ 5 .5mm nozzle. Printed in ABS at 240°, with the bed at 110° for the first layer and 92° for the rest. Note: I included the rib-retainer ring from the original thing if you wanted to keep it. I think it adds to the look, and it's easy enough to print/attach it if you wanted it to be a contrasting color in a different filament. UPDATED: I redid the fins with actual math instead of by eye. Yay CAD! Also reuploaded the file so that it wasn't just a single rib, but the whole, ribbed, body section. Original Model by TimeFramed, available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:331993

I wanted a quick way to clamp on a Mobius camera onto my bicycle handlebar and I already had a cheap plastic bicycle flashlight torch mount clamp, so I decided to remix one of the existing Mobius cam mounts to add on a barrel that would easily mount on one of these clamps. One nice thing about this design is that you can easily release the mount from the clamp and hold the Mobius camera freehand, and easily pop it back in. remixed_from.title: MeArm V0.4 - Pocket Sized Robot Arm

description.text:
This is a 3D printed robotic arm The intent was to design something "easy" and cheap to built with a good visual impact also. Test video: https://youtu.be/qovZKW0DxWk
https://youtu.be/N55W8TdMfCo I spent time to look around the web at some examples available that could be a good starting from, and between all I found interesting the phenoptix MeArm V4 project (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:360108) especially for the simplicity and low cost of parts involved.
So I kept only the kinematics geometry and redesign all parts including the gripper

23/09/15
updated instruction and round ramp stl (R01), added ball stl
preliminary tests video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x9C_3WHr1G0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0OFL6MxbPIM

25/09/15
updated gripper r01 files

04/10/15
added instructables link in instruction

I made an Instructables here : http://www.instructables.com/id/EEZYbotARM/ In all joint I use M4 screws with round head
For the vertical arm I prefer to guarantee a better precision using two brass pipes. the lower one stay in position kept by the servos, the upper one is crossed by a M3 screw (I'll post a better explaining image) First tests has been made with cheap servo sg90
http://www.servodatabase.com/servo/towerpro/sg90 than I changed the more stressed with metal gear servos MG90
http://www.servodatabase.com/servo/towerpro/mg90s
only for the claw I left the plastic one (but this can be of your choice) For driving the bot I made a lot of experiment using all the available method with arduino : sketches, potentiometers, joystick, WII nunchuck …. but at the end I discover a nice controller from Pololu that solves all the problem related to the servo driving in the easiest way. You can attach up to 6 – 12 – 24 servos depend of the controller type and it is provided with a software that give you the power to drive the servo in manual moving slides in the mean time you are able to set the values of speed and acceleration for any singular item. You can also build sequences of commands in a easy way, store them in the controller o get the code automatically. GREAT ! here the link of the Pololu servo controller
https://www.pololu.com/product/1352

I'm impressed by your work also, when I get time I would like to try using Kinet .
Unfortunately I got a mechanical background so I can't help about softwares and firmwares.
My conclusion is that doesn't depend all from the control board or firmware, but mainly is due to the fact that 9g servo are a little weak for the job. So when they're in rest position some spikes in the hold torque make them shaking. I try MG90 also that are a little stonger but not enought, and inevitably performance decay making the more overstressed begin to shake (on my robot arm appen on the vertical axis)
Unfortunately use stronger servos involve more costs, weight and space.

title: Dominion ExoKnight Lancer (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Well, the Wayfarer Tactics Kickstarter campaign is moving right along tanks to our amazing backers! We're a little over halfway through, but more rewards will be added soon, so be sure and check in and drop us a pledge! Here's the newest of the 18mm (Pocket-Tactics sized) versions of the Dominion ExoKnights, models that are featured in our B-tier rewards (28mm scale) which will feature into the eventual rules codex. They're a powerful division of the Trans-Universal Dominion that are able to act with autonomy, forgoing the usual labyrinthine protocol to act in the best interest of the worlds under their protection. The Lancer is deployed to deal with heavily armored enemy vehicles or monstrously sized biological enemies. Wayfarer Tactics is a dynamic miniature wargaming system. With these rules, you can use models from your collection to enact skirmishes, large-scale battles, or party-centered dungeon crawls. Based loosely on our Wayfarer multiverse setting, you can stage your battles in worlds of magic-rich high fantasy, far-flung intergalactic scifi, or anything in between. Check out our Kickstarter Video! In addition, we've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Wayfarer Tactics. Check it out here. Enjoy!
Printed at a .1 layer height with 0% infill. Assembled with model glue.
